title: Juncker calls Boris Johnson a ‘liar’ in fiery speech slating Brexit ‘bulls**t’
text:
Boris Johnson has been labelled a ‘liar’ in damning comments by Jean-Claude Juncker (Picture: EPA/European Commission)

Jean-Claude Juncker has hit out at the ‘bulls**t’ sold to the public by the British press during the referendum campaign.

The outgoing European Commission (EC) President slammed Boris Johnson for ‘lying’, and said he was so convinced Britain would vote Leave, he had even made a bet on it.

Speaking at a think tank event in Brussels this evening, Mr Juncker – who is set to be replaced by Ursula von der Leyen next Friday – also claimed it was a ‘major error’ to accept David Cameron’s request not to speak out over Brexit.

He explained: ‘David Cameron asked me not to intervene in the referendum campaign because he said the European Commission is even less popular on the islands than on the continent.

‘That was a major mistake, a major error. I should have intervened, because nobody was denying, contesting the lies Boris Johnson and others were spreading around.’

Slating the two British Prime Ministers and the media, Mr Juncker said the papers had spouted ‘nonsense’ and ‘bulls**t’ ‘day after day’ for 46 years.

He said the press had portrayed Britain as ‘not really in Europe… [only being there] for economic and internal market reasons’.

It is not the first time Mr Juncker has hit out at Brexit and key backers of the Leave campaign.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson (left) and Jean-Claude Juncke earlier this month (Picture: PA)

Earlier this week he labelled Brexit a ‘waste of time and energy’.

Singling out Mr Johnson for criticism tonight, he continued: ‘They were saying things, some of them – lying. Telling the people things which have nothing to do with our day by day reality.’

As a result, he said the outcome of the referendum was unsurprising, declaring himself ‘always convinced’ the referendum would be a ‘negative’ one.

He said he had bet a British commissioner that Leave would win, suggesting he would give him a euro if he was wrong, and that he be given a pound if he was right.

‘I have the pound in my pocket’, he said.

Defending the EC when asked what mistakes they had made under his leadership, he said the commission was not responsible for the result of the referendum and that it had not been part of the debate.

description: European Commission president criticises 'liar' Boris Johnson, David Cameron and British media over Brexit 'bulls**t'.
